metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network: automatic weather station of Zhangye wetland station, 2022
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from the automatic weather station (AWS) at the observation system of Zhangye wetland station from January 1 to December 31, 2022. The site (100.4464° E, 38.9751° N) was located on a wetland (reed surface) in Zhangye National Wetland Park, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1460 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (HMP45AC; 5 and 10 m, north), wind speed profile (03002; 5 and 10 m, north), wind direction profile (03002; 10 m, north), air pressure (CS100; 2 m), rain gauge (TE525M; 10 m), four-component radiometer (CNR1; 6 m, south), two infrared temperature sensors (SI-111; 6 m, south, vertically downward), soil heat flux (HFP01; 3 duplicates, -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (109ss-L; 0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2 and -0.4 m), and four photosynthetically active radiation (PQS-1; two above the plants, 6 m, south, one vertically downward and one vertically upward; two below the plants, 0.25 m, south, one vertically downward and one vertically upward).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_5 m and Ta_10 m; RH_5 m and RH_10 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_5 m and Ws_10 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_10 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm and Ts_40 cm) (℃), on the plants photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_U_up and PAR_U_down) (μmol/ (s m^2)), and below the plants photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_D_up and PAR_D_down) (μmol/ (s m^-2)).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2022-6-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used in arid and semiarid regions is the use of automatic weather stations which gather hydrometeorological data including radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. These stations collect data with a 10-minute average period.

Definition.Question: What does 'data quality control' mean in the context of meteorological data collection in arid regions?
Definition.Answer: Data quality control in the context of meteorological data collection in arid regions involves ensuring consistent data capture, removing duplicate records, deleting data that are evidently beyond physical meaning or instrument range, marking questionable data, and standardizing date and time formats.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations' in oasis–desert areas?
Definition.Answer: Energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas refer to the collection of data on the transfer of energy, water vapor, and carbon between the land surface and the atmosphere, typically involving measurements from land surface flux and meteorological stations, including auxiliary data like hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters.

Definition.Question: What is an 'automatic weather station' and how is it used in the context of collecting data in arid regions?
Definition.Answer: An automatic weather station is a facility equipped with instruments and sensors to automatically measure and record meteorological data such as temperature, humidity, air pressure, wind speed and direction, and precipitation. In arid regions, such stations are used to provide continuous, high-frequency data essential for understanding local climate dynamics and interactions in ecosystems like oases and deserts.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the measurement techniques for air temperature and humidity differ between meteorological stations located in the middle and lower reaches of river basins compared to those in wetland areas?
Comparison.Answer: Air temperature and humidity in wetland areas are measured using sensors at specific heights (5m and 10m) with a systematic orientation, while in river basins, they are part of broader hydrometeorological data collection efforts that include multiple parameters, possibly indicating a more integrated approach involving gradients of temperature and humidity.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of multiple sensor types for measuring atmospheric and soil parameters enhance the reliability of data interpretation in arid and semi-arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating multiple sensor types can enhance data reliability by providing a comprehensive view of the environmental conditions. Atmospheric parameters like temperature, humidity, and pressure, when measured at various heights, allow for detailed vertical profiling of the atmosphere. Similarly, soil temperature and heat flux sensors at different depths provide insights into subsurface conditions. This multi-layered approach helps in cross-verifying data, reducing uncertainty, and improving the robustness of interpretations related to energy, water, and carbon exchanges in arid and semi-arid regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the necessity for long-term observations in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observations are crucial to quantitatively understand the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, which is significant for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and protecting the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is ensuring the balance between oasis and desert systems critical for sustainable development?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Maintaining the balance is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area, supporting ecological security and sustainable development, as oases are crucial for the ecological environment and economic development in arid and semi-arid regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the degradation of ecological environments in inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Ecological environment degradation is caused by factors such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, particularly in inland river basins along the Silk Road.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of integrating long-term observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems on understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating long-term observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems can enhance the quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions. This knowledge is significant for protecting ecological stability and supporting sustainable development in oasis regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the establishment of multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations impact the quality and depth of data collected in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The establishment of multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations can improve the quality and depth of data collected by providing comprehensive and diverse observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, as well as hydrometeorological data and vegetation and soil parameters. This can lead to a more detailed understanding of environmental processes in arid regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the likely outcomes of utilizing a suite of observational datasets from oasis–desert systems for addressing ecological and socioeconomic challenges in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing a suite of observational datasets from oasis–desert systems can help address ecological and socioeconomic challenges by providing data essential for maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems. This can contribute to achieving sustainable oasis development, ecological security, and socioeconomic stability in arid regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the underlying goals of conducting long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals are to achieve a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas, which is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions, protecting the ecological stability, supporting the socioeconomic development of oases, and achieving the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in the context of sustainable development?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems is critical to support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis, as these regions are essential for the ecological environment and economic development, especially in arid and semiarid areas.

Goal Orientation.Question: What motivates the inclusion of auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters in datasets focused on oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Including auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters helps provide a comprehensive understanding of the interactions within oasis–desert systems, supporting the analysis of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes and aiding in the protection and sustainable development of these areas.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are data collection and quality control processes designed to handle missing or erroneous data in climatic datasets?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection process involves ensuring a consistent data acquisition rate, with 144 data points collected each day at 10-minute intervals. Quality control includes marking missing data with a placeholder value (-6999), removing duplicate records, and discarding data that exceed physical or instrument limits. Any data marked with red highlights are flagged for potential issues. A unified format for date and time is maintained to ensure consistency across records.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the comprehensive monitoring of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: The use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for half-hourly turbulent flux data collection, along with automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data, enables comprehensive monitoring in these ecosystems.

Enablement.Question: How do data quality control measures ensure the reliability of meteorological datasets collected from arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: Data quality control measures such as ensuring a specific number of daily data points, marking missing data, removing duplicates, and excluding out-of-range measurements help ensure dataset reliability.

Enablement.Question: In what ways can the integration of auxiliary data like vegetation and soil parameters enhance the understanding of oasis–desert systems?
Enablement.Answer: Integrating auxiliary data like vegetation and soil parameters with energy, water vapor, and carbon flux observations provides a more comprehensive understanding of interactions within oasis–desert systems, supporting ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected challenges in maintaining long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert systems, and how might these challenges affect data accuracy and reliability?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, and dust storms. These conditions present challenges for maintaining accurate and reliable datasets over long periods.

Expectation.Question: Why might certain hydrometeorological data, such as soil temperature profiles and groundwater table data, be expected to have high variability in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: High variability in hydrometeorological data can be expected due to the unique ecological landscape of oases in arid regions, which significantly affect energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, influencing soil temperature profiles and groundwater levels.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated benefits of integrating auxiliary data involving vegetation and soil parameters with meteorological observations in understanding oasis–desert interactions?
Expectation.Answer: Integrating auxiliary data with meteorological observations helps in achieving a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and ensuring ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases.

Judgmental.Question: What are the perceived challenges in maintaining data quality and continuity in long-term meteorological studies in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges in maintaining data quality and continuity include dealing with data gaps, ensuring accurate calibration of sensors, and managing environmental factors that might affect measurements, such as extreme weather conditions. The data processing steps, such as removing data with obvious physical inconsistencies and marking doubtful data, are crucial in addressing these challenges.

Assertion.Question: I'm not clear on what challenges researchers face when collecting long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in oasis–desert ecosystems.
Assertion.Answer: Researchers face challenges such as ecological environment degradation, including drying up of rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These issues can impact the stability of observations and the physical conditions where data is collected, adding complexity to maintaining continuous high-quality datasets.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection methods used for capturing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods involve using observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis-desert systems, which include long-term measurements of energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, and auxiliary data related to hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. The primary instruments are the eddy covariance system and scintillometer for half-hourly turbulent flux data, and automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data with a 10-minute average period.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in collecting data in inland river basins within arid and semiarid areas.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in collecting data in these regions include ecological environment degradation such as drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensified land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These issues are prevalent in inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, impacting data collection efforts.

Request/Directive.Question: Please suggest potential strategies for expanding or refining datasets related to oasis-desert systems in arid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: A potential strategy could include establishing additional land surface flux and meteorological stations in critical areas to capture more detailed spatial variations. Also, integrating remote sensing data with field observations could enhance spatial and temporal coverage. Long-term and continuous data collection, along with comprehensive data processing and quality control procedures, would ensure dataset reliability and usefulness.
